annotation.TEXT: John Dortmunder is a career criminal who is the main character in a series of comic novels and short stories by Donald Westlake.
Daylight Saving Time was originally proposed in England by an outdoorsman who wanted more daylight time for golfing.
In the mid-‘60s, before his solo career, Nugent was part of the psychedelic rock band The Amboy Dukes, despite the fact that he was ardently anti-drugs.
Mr. Limpet’s adventures under the sea included fighting Nazi submarines. We’re not kidding.
Martinis are a type of alcoholic cocktail made with gin and vermouth and usually garnished with olives or lemon rind. They were first served in the late 1800s.
Fame is a 1980 musical film about students at the New York High School of Performing Arts (a real place). The film spawned two TV shows, a stage show, and a 2009 remake.
Hamlet is a play by William Shakespeare, written sometime around 1600. The title role is considered one of the greatest challenges for an actor.
In WWI, poorly trained civilians promoted to first lieutenants often shirked their duties. Enlisted men called them “goldbrickers” because their rank insignia was a single gold bar.
The saying “If the van’s a-rockin’, don’t come a-knockin’” likely dates to the ‘60s & ‘70s, when vans began to acquire shag carpets and other amenities.
A paraphrased line from the film Stand By Me, from a scene in which the kids are sitting around a campfire.
Sherlock Holmes’ smarter brother, played by Wilder, was named Sigerson.
Gymnast Cathy Rigby went on to become an actress, including a successful Broadway revival of Peter Pan, and a spokesperson for Stayfree pads.
The Winter Garden Theatre is one of Broadway’s most famous theaters; its longest-running tenant was Cats.
Ramses was a common name among Egyptian pharaohs. Ramses II (aka Ramses the Great) was well-known for building more cities and temples throughout his reign.
The music video for Billy Idol’s “Dancing with Myself” has Idol performing for a rag-clad audience in a post-apocalyptic wasteland.
In addition to serving as the 41st US president, George H.W. Bush has been vice president, ambassador to the UN, congressman, and director of the CIA.
That’s Dancing! is a 1985 documentary that looked back at dancing in film, with clips from Fame, The Wizard of Oz, Oklahoma!, etc.
McLean Stevenson played Henry Blake on the TV show M*A*S*H. After he left the show, he starred on four failed sitcoms over the next several years.
The Six Flags of the amusement park chain are the six nations that have controlled Texas: Spain, France, Mexico, the Republic of Texas, the US, and the CSA.
“The only thing we have to fear is … fear itself,” is a line from President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s first inauguration in March 1933, when the country was still gripped by the Great Depression.
A Pampers ad campaign in the ‘80s expressed sympathy for any baby stuck in “a saggy diaper that leaks.”
Lava lamps are a ‘60s icon: a diamond-shaped glass tube filled with colored liquid and a waxy ooze that flows in ways fascinating to people under the influence of mind-altering chemicals.
A translation of the famous epigram by French journalist Jean-Baptiste Alphonse Karr: “Plus ça change, plus c’est la même chose.”
Venerable TV journalist Sam Donaldson, who appeared on ABC News for more than 4 decades, has been mocked for his unnatural helmet of hair for years.
Call waiting has been available since the early ‘70s, although by the ‘80s, the practice was considered impolite.
Bob Fosse was the choreographer and director behind some of the all-time classic musicals of the 20th century, including Cabaret and Sweet Charity.
Boys Town, a home for troubled kids in Omaha, uses as its symbol a boy carrying another on his back with the legend “He ain’t heavy, Father, he’s my brother.” The Hollies based a song on the saying.
With annotations provided by The Annotated MST website.
Norm Abram (not Abramson) is a TV personality who has appeared on the PBS home improvement show This Old House since 1979 and has always been called “master carpenter.”
The popular anti-communist slogan “Better dead than Red” was originally coined by the Nazis during WWII (“Lieber tot als rot”).
A reference to Hungarian socialite/actress sisters Eva (known for Green Acres), Zsa Zsa (known for her nine husbands), and Magda Gabor (known for … well, nothing you’ve ever seen).
For most of the past century of filmmaking, matte paintings were hand painted on glass, which was placed in front of the camera while an unpainted section framed the actors.
A paraphrased line from the 1939 film The Wizard of Oz, spoken by the Scarecrow to Dorothy and signaling the arrival of Glinda, the Good Witch of the North.
Dorothy’s three faithful companions along the Yellow Brick Road to the Emerald City in the film The Wizard of Oz.
In a scene in the 1984 mockumentary This Is Spinal Tap, the band gets hopelessly lost in a maze of corridors on their way to the stage for a concert in Cleveland.
In 2000, the World Wide Fund for Nature sued World Wrestling Federation over the copyright for WWF and won; the wrestlers changed their name to World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE).
In filmmaking, the key grip is the lead crewmember in charge of placing lighting, tracks, and other camera equipment.
Robot Holocaust: Fully annotated by The Official MST3K YouTube Channel.
A paraphrased line from the Twilight Zone episode “Nothing in the Dark.” That episode starred a young Robert Redford as Death.
Heavy metal band Metallica’s videos tend to involve a lot of long hair, strobe lights, and guitars.
According to Trace Beaulieu, Crow simplified the entire animal kingdom into either “doggies” or “kitties,” though most of the time he just said “kitty.”
Mumbley-peg (or mumblety-peg) was a 19th-century game that involved kids tossing knives as close as possible to their feet. Loser had to pull a peg from the ground with their teeth.
The DeLorean Motor Co. produced only one vehicle: the DMC-12, made famous by the ‘80s Back to the Future trilogy.
A play on the taglines for many police-oriented TV shows and films. This riff may be referencing a ‘70s TV series called Holmes & Yoyo, which paired a human and an android.
“Little buddy” was the Skipper’s frequent nickname for Gilligan in the ‘60s TV show Gilligan’s Island.
“Underoos are fun to wear” was part of the ad jingle for the children’s underwear line, which featured licensed designs ranging from superheroes to the Dukes of Hazzard.
Rodgers and Hart were a prolific songwriting duo in the early 20th century; their works include “Isn’t It Romantic?” and “My Funny Valentine.”
A paraphrase of animated superhero Underdog’s speech when he transformed, with the help of a pill he kept in his ring. In the ‘70s they edited out all references to the pill, for the kids’ sake.
Actress/singer Eartha Kitt’s most famous role was as Catwoman in the third season of the TV series Batman; her biggest musical hit was 1953’s “Santa Baby.”
Nugent is known for his controversial political opinions. For example, in 1990, he argued against South Africa’s repeal of apartheid, saying, “All men are not created equal.”
George Clinton is one of the founders of Parliament-Funkadelic (P-Funk), a soul/funk band that was huge during the ‘70s.
Don’t put anything in the mouth of someone who’s having a seizure; just move anything they might hit and hurt themselves, and put them on their left side when the seizure is over.
“Run away!” was screamed by King Arthur (Graham Chapman) in the film Monty Python and the Holy Grail as the French hurled cows at his party.
Kleenex was introduced in 1924 and has become an informal brand eponym for all such facial tissues.
GLOW (Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling) was a women’s wrestling league in the ‘80s, with stars like Jailbait, Big Bad Mama, and Matilda the Hun.
In the opening scene of Star Wars, Darth Vader lifts Captain Antilles off the ground by his throat and crushes his neck.
The 843-acre Central Park in Manhattan, which was established in 1857, is one of the greatest public spaces in the country.
The Wiz was a contemporary, urban-set, and African-American-focused retelling of The Wizard of Oz. The film version starred Diana Ross, Richard Pryor, and Michael Jackson.
The ‘50s-era Ford Edsel is generally considered a marketing disaster, selling far fewer cars than anticipated and being taken off the market within a few years.
Cow-shaped cream pitchers date back to 18th-century Holland; they became very popular in England, where they were made both in stoneware and in silver.
Along with “rhubarb” and “watermelon,” background extras mutter “peas and carrots” among themselves to simulate conversation in TV shows and films.
A long-standing urban legend claims that Walt Disney’s cryogenically frozen corpse is hidden under this ride. In fact he was cremated.
Dr. Seuss’s One Fish Two Fish Red Fish Blue Fish is a children’s book first published in 1960.
In 1979 the US-backed Shah of Iran fled the country and was replaced by an Islamic theocracy under the Ayatollah Khomeini, which instituted strict religious laws.
Rust-Oleum is a company founded by sea captain Robert Fergusson that makes protective paints and sealants. It was a family-owned company until 1994.
World-famous clown Emmett Kelly’s best-known routine involved him trying to “sweep” his spotlight into a dustpan.
Thanks for watching this fully-annotated presentation of Robot Holocaust!
After Pee-wee Herman’s bike is stolen in the film Pee-wee’s Big Adventure, a psychic tells him it is hidden in the basement of the Alamo in San Antonio. The Alamo has no basement.
A “mark” in filmmaking parlance is the place where an actor is supposed to stand, usually denoted by a piece of tape on the floor.
An imitation of the “Necktie Killer” in Alfred Hitchcock’s 1972 film Frenzy.
In wrestling matches, it is common for folding chairs (aka card chairs) to be used against opponents.
Brought to you by the Official MST3K YouTube Channel.
Kukla, Fran and Ollie was a TV show featuring puppets that was intended for children, but adults were soon attracted to it as well.
“Ron Howard pops the clutch and tells the world to eat my dust!” is a line from the trailer for the 1976 film Eat My Dust.
“Itsy Bitsy Spider” (aka “Eency Weency Spider,” “Ipsy Dipsy Spider,” etc.) is a children’s nursery rhyme and song first published in the early 20th century.
Actress Mary Tyler Moore was considered a fashion trendsetter, from the unprecedented capri pants she wore on The Dick Van Dyke Show to the pantsuits she sported on The Mary Tyler Moore Show.
On the TV show Family Affair, Mr. French (played by Sebastian Cabot) was the valet who helped his bachelor employer care for three orphans. His first name was actually Giles.
The device they’re standing in front of may be a processing machine produced by Worthington Industries, founded in 1955.
And now, we invite you to enjoy…the fully-annotated Robot Holocaust!
Sisters Ann (vocals) and Nancy Wilson (guitar) front Heart.
Mao Zedong was the leader of the Chinese Revolution in the late ‘40s/early ‘50s. Actual anagram for Chairman Mao: I am on a march.
A line from ‘70s ads for Mennen Skin Bracer aftershave. One starred a young, comparatively thin John Goodman.
Lines from the song “I Hope I Get It,” from the 1975 musical A Chorus Line.
“Jack and the Beanstalk” is a traditional English fairy tale dating back to the early 1700s (though oral versions go back much further).
Did we miss any references? Be sure to let us know in the comments!
Film/TV producer Aaron Spelling’s mansion in LA was criticized for its size (123 rooms; 56,500 sq. ft.) and ostentatiousness when it was built in 1988.
Actor/singer Rex Smith is known for his 1979 top 10 hit “You Take My Breath Away” and for playing motorcycle vigilante Jesse Mach in the ‘80s TV series Street Hawk.
A 2010 study showed that alcohol affects the portion of the brain that detects symmetry—and people are attracted to symmetrical faces.
Sylvester Stallone both wrote and starred in Rocky, which won three Oscars and took in more than $225 million on a budget of roughly $1 million.
Moe Howard of the Three Stooges hurled this insult at a bearded man (played by regular Stooges foil Vernon Dent) in the 1949 short Malice in the Palace.
Englishman George Cayley invented the first seat belts in the early 1800s to test his aircraft, including a biplane prototype and several early gliders.
The Beatles were, arguably, the most influential popular music group of all time. Ravi Shankar’s association with The Beatles helped introduce Indian music to the West.
Abram had his own show, The New Yankee Workshop, from 1989-2009.
Armageddon is the epic battle prophesied in the Book of Revelation; some Christians believe it will take place at Tel Megiddo in Israel.
Buckwheat (played by Billie Thomas) was a character in the Our Gang/Little Rascals shorts; he is remembered for his wild hair, bugged-out eyes, and odd speech inflections.
In the Don Knotts live action/animated film The Incredible Mr. Limpet, Crusty was a hermit crab voiced by Paul Frees; Ladyfish was voiced by Elizabeth MacRae.
Actor Robert Culp appeared on the TV shows I Spy and The Greatest American Hero, among many others.
Huggies is a brand of disposable diaper. They were test marketed in 1968 but not sold until 1978, after Pampers had crushed the company’s first foray into the market, Kimbies.
A reference to a TV ad for Life cereal, which ran from 1972-1984, making it one of the longest-lived commercials ever.
An imitation of Jan Gabriel, a Chicago motorsports announcer who recorded the original “Sunday! Sunday! Sunday!” ad in 1968 and continued to do variations on the theme through the ‘80s.
On the TV game show The Price Is Right, the prizes were often revealed in this manner, along with the announcer’s excited bellowing.
The line “I’ll be back again and again” was often heard in TV ads for Cats in the ‘80s, spoken by enthusiastic theatergoers.
Peking duck is traditionally served with steamed bao buns.
Tropes from various TV ads for products such as the Veg-O-Matic by Ronco. “But wait, there’s more” was used as far back as the ‘50s by Ronco founder Ron Popeil.
This is a minced oath, meaning an ordinary word substituted for a stronger one (like “God”). In this case “Mike” derives from Mick, or Irishman.
“Free Bird” is a 1973 Lynyrd Skynyrd song that became infamous for having audiences yell it out at concerts as a song request, regardless of who was performing.
The syndicated TV series Solid Gold usually featured snippets from the Top 10 hits of the week while a bevy of dancers performed.
The UN complex in NYC was designed by Oscar Niemeyer and Le Corbusier and completed in 1952.
An Australian record label took the name “Hello Cleveland!” after this scene.
The longtime slogan for Dial antibacterial soap, introduced in 1953, was “Aren’t you glad you use Dial? Don’t you wish everybody did?”
Reggae group UB40 released a cover of Neil Diamond’s “Red Red Wine” in 1983, which topped charts around the world.
John Clayton, Viscount Greystoke, is the birth name of Tarzan, the fictional king of the jungle created by Edgar Rice Burroughs in 1912.
Bolas are cords with weighted balls at each end that wrap around the body of the opponent when thrown. They have been found in China, S. America, and prehistoric N. America.
The phrase “Meanwhile, back at _____” originated with title cards in silent films. In westerns, it was often “Meanwhile, back at the ranch ...”
The Actors’ Equity Association, or Equity, is an American labor union that represents live stage performers, as opposed to film and TV actors.
“Stuffing Kleenex” refers to the practice of young women putting tissues in their brassieres to enhance their … attributes.
Elmer Fudd is a hunter with a speech impediment in Warner Bros.’ Looney Tunes cartoons; he first appeared in 1940’s Elmer’s Candid Camera.
Get the inside scoop behind every reference in the episode.
Godspell is a musical based on the Gospel of Matthew, the first book of the New Testament. It ran off-Broadway for 5 years and then for 500 performances on Broadway.
Cincinnati was originally named Losantiville; it was renamed for a society of war veterans, who in turn were named after a Roman general.
Hello, Larry was one of McLean Stevenson’s failed sitcoms, in which he played a radio show host. Critics reviled the show as unfunny and unlikeable. It lasted two seasons.
The school’s cafeteria was often the scene of some “spontaneous” singing and dancing.
Indian musician Ravi Shankar is known for his mastery of the sitar, a stringed instrument.
The park is currently visited by about 42 million people every year.
The mattress tag warning is actually directed at manufacturers and retailers, to prevent them from passing off old mattresses as new, as they had in the past.
On the sitcom Gilligan’s Island, Mary Ann Summers was the country girl and Ginger Grant was the movie star. “Ginger or Mary Ann?” was a long-standing debate among fans.
Underdog’s secret identity was as a “humble and lovable” shoeshine boy.
“To err is human; to forgive, divine” is a famous bit of poetic philosophy published in 1711 as part of An Essay on Criticism, written by Alexander Pope.
Gorton’s of Gloucester is another frozen seafood company. It was started in 1874 by an out-of-work cotton mill superintendent in Gloucester, MA.
Journalist Barbara Walters is famous for her in-depth interviews as well as her odd manner of speaking, which was mocked by Gilda Radner on SNL with her character Baba Wawa.
Stalactites hang down from the ceiling; stalagmites grow up from the ground. Remember: C for ceiling, G for ground.
Robin Williams was an actor and comedian who got his start in the San Francisco standup comedy scene.
Filet-O-Fish is a fish sandwich sold by McDonald’s. It was created by a franchise owner in Cincinnati to appeal to Catholic customers who swore off meat on Fridays.
Jazz trumpeter Miles Davis is regarded as one of the most influential musicians of the 20th century.
Lancelot Link, Secret Chimp was a kids’ spy spoof show in the ‘70s featuring chimpanzees with dubbed voices: Lancelot Link, Mata Hairi, and nemesis Baron von Butcher.
A line from the 1967 Beatles song “I Am the Walrus.”
Peter Tork was a member of the ‘60s pop group The Monkees, who had their own TV show for two years.
Charles Ogier de Batz de Castelmore, Comte d’Artagnan, was captain of the Musketeers for French King Louis XIV. Alexandre Dumas based the character in The Three Musketeers on him.
Muslin is a cotton fabric thought to originate in Bangladesh. It became wildly popular for women’s clothing in Europe in the 18th century.
R2-D2 is an astromech droid that served the queen of Naboo. C-3PO is a protocol droid built by Anakin Skywalker on Tatooine. They have both appeared in all the Star Wars films thus far.
The lisping Daffy Duck is another Warner Bros.’ Looney Tunes character who first appeared in the 1937 short Porky’s Duck Hunt.
Beltone is a hearing aid manufacturer founded by Sam Posen in Chicago in 1940.
Beauty and the Beast was a TV drama that starred Linda Hamilton as the Beauty and Ron Perlman in cat-like makeup as Vincent (the Beast).
As an avocado, he’s a fruit. Technically, he’s a berry.
“Penny them in there” is a prank in which you jam pennies between the door and the door jamb (on the side with the hinges) until you can’t open the door.
The first known published use of the word cooties is in 1917, in relation to the lice picked up in the trenches.
A favorite riff imitating Lloyd Bridges, who starred in the syndicated TV show Sea Hunt as scuba diver Mike Nelson.
Vivarin is an over-the-counter caffeine pill, similar to NoDoz. “Revive with Vivarin” was their ad tagline for many years.
An imitation of Norville “Shaggy” Rogers on the Scooby-Doo animated TV series. He was voiced by Casey Kasem, the well-known syndicated DJ.
The song “Revolution 9” by The Beatles is often referred to as “avant garde,” or “crap”; it includes odd musical sweeps, random noises, distortion, and the repeated phrase “number nine.”
Its fans included such luminaries as Orson Welles, John Steinbeck, and Adlai Stevenson.
Ted Nugent has long been an ardent Second Amendment advocate and serves on the board of the National Rifle Association.
The song “Jimmy Crack Corn” is credited to the Virginia Minstrels, a 19th-century blackface minstrel group.
In the late ‘80s and into the ‘90s, ads for Obsession perfume were, shall we say, pretentious: black and white, slow motion, orchestral music, non sequitur dialogue, and mostly insufferable.
Queens is the largest (geographically) of NYC’s 5 boroughs. Nearly half of its 2 million residents are foreign-born, coming from more than 100 nations.
The Munchkins tell Dorothy this several times in the 1939 film The Wizard of Oz.
Reuben Kincaid (played by Dave Madden) was the Partridge Family’s manager on the ‘70s sitcom of that name.
Barbara Walters asked this in her infamous 1981 interview with actress Katharine Hepburn. In fact, Hepburn had first claimed she was a tree(!), but Walters is still mocked for it.
Mad Max is a 1979 movie starring the then-unknown Mel Gibson as a leather-clad anti-hero in a post-apocalyptic world.
In the original Battlestar Galactica TV show, Cylons were robots created by an extinct alien race out to destroy humanity: chrome-covered humanoids with a single scanning red eye.
Cats is a stage musical by composer Andrew Lloyd Webber. Its London production ran for 21 years, while the Broadway show ran for 18 years.
E-Z Mart is a Texas-based chain of convenience stores with hundreds of locations, mostly in the south.
Bolo, or shoestring, ties are synonymous with Western wear and date back to the late 1800s.
The cover of Ted Nugent’s 1980 album Scream Dream features him in a loincloth not unlike Kai’s.
Mannix was a TV show about a PI in Los Angeles (played by Mike Connors) who indulged in frequent car chases, shootouts, and fistfights.
After the peak of his solo career, Nugent joined the “supergroup” Damn Yankees, which included members of the rock bands Styx and Night Ranger.
American Gladiators was a syndicated TV show that had amateur athletes competing against professional wrestler types with names like Turbo and Nitro.
The music video for the Grateful Dead’s biggest commercial hit, 1987’s “Touch of Grey,” briefly featured the band (including lead singer Jerry Garcia) as skeletons.
Three Rivers Stadium was located in Pittsburgh and housed the Pirates and the Steelers for 30 years, until it was demolished in 2001.
Billy Idol is a rock musician who hit it big in the ‘80s with hits like “White Wedding” and “Rebel Yell.”
Let us know if we missed any references!
Also a reference to the Gene Wilder film The Adventure of Sherlock Holmes’ Smarter Brother.
Julie Newmar is an actress and singer best known for playing Catwoman in the first two seasons of the ‘60s TV series Batman.
Wheel of Fortune is a long-running syndicated TV game show, which first aired in 1975.
Ads for Hanes underwear in the ‘80s featured Inspector 12 (Polly Rowles), harassing her fellow inspectors into doing a good job.
Did we somehow miss a reference? Let us know in the comments!
Micky Dolenz and Mike Nesmith (and Davy Jones) were the other members of The Monkees along with Peter Tork.
Arthur Treacher’s Fish & Chips is a small chain of fast food restaurants that serve British-style fish and chips. It is named after an English character actor.
Many bands have gotten lost backstage. The lead singer for Belle & Sebastian wandered off once during an instrumental break and wound up in a shopping center.
Albino blues/jazz/experimental musician Edgar Winter’s best-known song is “Frankenstein,” which hit #1 in 1973.
Actor/comedian Jonathan Winters played Mork and Mindy’s elderly baby on that TV show (he hatched from an egg and aged backwards).
Paraphrased lyrics from the film’s theme song by Irene Cara, which was a hit on its own and won an Oscar for Best Original Song.
Recipes for s’mores have appeared as early as 1927.
A couple of lines from the 1980 Ted Nugent song “Wango Tango.” Maserati is an Italian car maker founded in 1914, known for their high-end vehicles.
Bobby “The Brain” Heenan (derisively called “The Weasel”) is a former wrestling manager/commentator famous for always rooting for the “heel” (that is, the bad guy of the match).
Balloon juice is slang dating back to the early part of the 20th century that means nonsense talk; it is derived from the “hot air” that fills the balloon.
DePaul University’s men’s basketball team, the Blue Demons, is in fact revered, despite having won only one national championship, in 1945.
In bowling, if a player knocks down all the pins in two tries, it’s called a spare (as opposed to a strike: knocking them all down on one go).
Once talkies came in, the phrase was still used by narrators for films and radio and TV shows.
Probably a reference to a line in the 1981 Sylvester Stallone film Nighthawks: “I’ll cut you, man!”
Murray’s Restaurant has been a popular steakhouse and cocktail lounge in Minneapolis since 1946.
Truman Capote was an author and actor best known for writing Breakfast at Tiffany’s and In Cold Blood. He is also remembered for his odd voice.
Lily Munster was played by Yvonne De Carlo on the original Munsters TV show. On the ‘80s remake, The Munsters Today, she was played by onetime Catwoman and Miss America Lee Meriwether.
“Cat Scratch Fever” is a song by Ted Nugent, off the 1977 album of the same name.
A paraphrase of a line from Prince’s 1984 song “When Doves Cry.”
Heart is a hard rock band formed in 1973 that has had several hits, including “Magic Man” and “Barracuda.”
The phrase “Sometimes a cigar is just a cigar” is attributed (without much evidence) to Sigmund Freud.
Despite yelling “Cleveland” as they’re lost backstage, the band is actually in Chicago at the time.
Pepto-Bismol is an OTC medicine for relief of diarrhea and nausea invented in 1901 by a New York doctor.
The cover to David Lee Roth’s first solo album, Eat ‘Em and Smile, featured his face in vibrant tribal paint and feathers.
A paraphrase of the first lines of the 1976 Stephen Bishop song “Save It for a Rainy Day.”
Comedian Don Knotts is perhaps best known as bumbling deputy Barney Fife on The Andy Griffith Show and as suspicious landlord Ralph Furley on Three’s Company.
“Zactlies” is a bit of charming slang: after a night of drinking, your mouth tastes (or smells) “zactly” like one’s, ahem, anus.
Yards of Leather is a porn film apparently invented by Best Brains.
A parody of Nick the bartender’s line in the film It’s a Wonderful Life: “Get me! I’m givin’ out wings!”
Shelley Duvall is a slender actress whose best-known role is as Wendy Torrance in the horror film The Shining.
The reactions of the other actors in the famous “chestburster” scene in Alien are genuine: they had seen the creature’s design, but didn’t know it would be that gruesome.
Adjusted for inflation, the series of James Bond films is the second-highest-grossing in history, topped only by Star Wars.
A line from the song “Stranger in Paradise,” from the 1953 musical Kismet. Six versions hit the charts in 1955, including ones by Bing Crosby and Tony Bennett.
Brides of Funkenstein was a funk group that collaborated with P-Funk. Their biggest hit was 1978’s “Disco to Go.”
In the Shakespeare play Hamlet, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are friends of Hamlet’s who agree to spy on him for Hamlet’s uncle and get killed for their efforts.
The famous “Shakespeare in the Park” in NYC’s Central Park has boasted performances by George C. Scott, James Earl Jones, and Meryl Streep, among others.
Rolling Stones front man Mick Jagger famously has a big mouth. John Pasche, who designed the band’s famous lips-and-tongue logo, has said he was inspired by the size of Jagger’s kisser.
Tork sported a Beatles-esque moptop with sideburns.
A riff on the early ‘20s quip by actor Walter Catlett and the song “If We’d Known You Was Gonna Come, We’d a Surely Baked a Cake” by Leslie Jeffries. Eileen Barton had a similar hit in the ‘50s.
Arsenio Hall is an actor and TV host best known for his early ‘90s late-night talk show The Arsenio Hall Show.
Angie Dickinson’s role as Sgt. Pepper Anderson in Police Woman brought her new fame for her revolving array of pantsuits.
Two years before this show aired there was the longest writers’ strike in history: 22 weeks in 1988.
H. Salt Esq. is another fish & chips chain, this one founded in California in 1965 and still largely confined to that state.
Given our aging population and plummeting birth rate, diaper manufacturers expect adult diapers like Depends will outsell baby diapers sometime within the next decade.
After Pee-wee Herman’s bike is stolen in the film Pee-wee’s Big Adventure, a psychic tells him it is hidden in the basement of the Alamo in San Antonio. The Alamo has no basement.
Peter Pan first appeared in J.M. Barrie’s The Little White Bird: a mischievous boy who was able to fly and never grew old.
Engine run-on occurs when a hot spot in a car’s engine continues to ignite gas after it has been turned off. It usually happens in cars with carburetors.
“Walk the Dog” is a popular yoyo trick in which the yoyo moves along the floor before being brought back up to the hand. World record distance is 22 feet.
In the famous scene in the film A Streetcar Named Desire in which Marlon Brando shrieks “Stellaaaaa!”, he is clad in a torn T-shirt that is falling off one shoulder.
Wendy Melvoin and Lisa Coleman, aka Wendy & Lisa, were members of Prince’s band, the Revolution, in the ‘80s; they have also released several solo albums.
Rastafarianism, the Jamaican religious movement, began in the ‘30s with Marcus Garvey and the coronation of Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie.
The entertainment phenomenon known as Renaissance Festivals began in Southern California in the ‘60s.
Mrs. Paul’s packaged seafood was founded by Edward Piszek and John Paul. They named it after John’s mother because they were sick of Edward’s mom pressuring them to name it after her.
The punchline to an old joke about a horse walking into a bar.
Chi-Chi’s was a chain of inexpensive Mexican restaurants. The first location opened in Minneapolis in 1975; the last location in the US closed in 2004.
A paraphrased variant of a mnemonic for tying a bowline knot.
The Bangles were a girl band during the ‘80s who hit it big with songs like “Walk Like an Egyptian” and “Manic Monday.”
